content.description: All the moves are relatively the same difficulty. Start on crimp to the right side and corner left. Work your way to the top. Do a sketchyish topout on good sloper left and meat hook right.
content.protection: Two pads - one for the climb and one for potentially bad fall to the left.

content.description: On the right side of a small boulder, there is a nice clean arete. The arete is split in two parts by big boulder wedged in between the corner of the arete and the boulder next to it. Without using the boulder to your right for your feet, start sitting with your right hand on a good hidden edge on the right side of the arete. Balance on a good foothold, and reach up to good hold just above the wedged boulder on the arete. Finish up the arete from there. I think there is potential for an eliminate that avoids the arete after the wedge and utilizes some cools slopers on the face, maybe V6ish.
content.location: You can see this from the trail that runs along the length of Goat Rock. It's about 25' past the "What's for Dinner?" ledge on the right and one tier below.

content.description: Climb the obvious, left-trending crack/lip. Start at the far right.
Start on a small flake, and make a dynamic move up and to the right to a jug. Go up the jug ladder to an easy topout.
content.location: The route goes under two triangular jugs. The route is on the right side.

content.description: Stinging Surprises is a great route that is pretty highball and varies in style. It starts with powerful moves out of a roof then transitions into a vertical compression section with an airy topout.Start on a jug under the roof, and climb out of the roof on mostly good holds, sticking to the right side of the roof is easiest. Climb straight up and transition into compressing between the arete and a good sidepull rail. The topout on good holds, but be careful as you're quite high off of a not so good landing.A video of the FA: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=i_e4ow0qxSE.
content.protection: At least 4 or 5 pads - the landing is downhill and pretty bad. You will definitely want some spotters as well.
content.location: This is on a boulder around the corner to the right of Goat Rock and is perched high up on the hill.

content.description: Sit start just in front of tree on good edges. Trend right using a broken sidepull, and then transition into the good edges of Ripple Affect (crux). Finish up on Ripple Affect.
content.location: It is on the face that shares a small ledge with What's For Dinner?.

content.description: Start on the right side of the wall. I chose to kind of squat start on the lowest edges to get the most out of the climb. Follow the "ripples" of diagonal edges to the top. This is a pretty fun climb. With some traffic, it should lose some of the small, crumbly pebbles you can feel displace with your feet as you climb. The topout can be a little heady if you look behind you and feel like you're 25 feet up, because you're looking beyond the ledge below you. That said, the topout is all cleaned up and rather easy.
content.location: It is on the face that shares a small ledge with What's For Dinner?.

content.description: An easy start leads to a tricky mantel on a small ledge, then stand up and reach for a ledge on the right, and top out. It is kinda dirty.
content.protection: A few pads, the mantel is a little sketchy.
content.location: Start on a right-facing jug, make some layback moves to a small dirty ledge, and mantel. Top out on a ledge to the right.*This is on the slab to the right of where a big, detached block and a bunch of cracks are.

content.description: Start on Dirty Crack, and then finish up the right-trending crack. This is the better of the two lines, the right-trending crack seems to have good slots right where you need them.
content.location: It is on the small ledge where "What's For Dinner?" is. This is on the left side of the small face just to the right of the "What's For Dinner?" block.

content.description: Dirty Crack is the obvious crack on the left side of the just less-than-vertical face. The last couple of feet after the crack splits is pretty filthy and maybe perpetually wet - we will have to see after a bit of a dry spell. You can sit start this to add a little difficulty, but it's awkward and not that great.
content.location: This is on the small ledge where "What's For Dinner?" is. This is on the left side of the small face just to the right of the "What's For Dinner?" block.

content.description: Start on a diagonal ledge, and mantel to a good edge. From there, go straight up for an easy topout.
content.location: The route starts directly in the middle of the face. The route is on a separate face right off the walking trail.

content.description: Goat Rock is a 20-40 foot cliff band with varied features including a refrigerator-sized, detached block. There is potential for a dozen quality routes from slab to overhung.
